entry.title: China lodges complaint about Japan official visiting Taiwan
entry.summary: China has lodged a diplomatic complaint with Japan regarding the visit by a high-ranking official of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party to Taiwan, the Chinese foreign ministry said on Monday.

entry.title: China hits EU dairy products with provisional duties
entry.summary: China will impose provisional duties of 21.9% to 42.7% on certain dairy products imported from the European Union starting on December 23, following an anti-subsidy probe that began more than a year ago.

entry.title: Trump shook up global trade this year; some uncertainty may persist in 2026
entry.summary: President Donald Trump's return to the White House in 2025 kicked off a frenetic year for global trade, with waves of tariffs on U.S. trading partners that lifted import taxes to their highest since the Great Depression, roiled financial markets and sparked rounds of negotiations over trade and investment deals.

entry.title: China leaves benchmark lending rates unchanged for seventh straight month
entry.summary: China left benchmark loan prime rates (LPRs) unchanged for the seventh consecutive month in December on Monday, matching market expectations.

entry.title: Asia shares extend tech rally, yen under pressure
entry.summary: Asian share markets rose on Monday tracking tech-driven gains on Wall Street, while the yen wallowed at all-time lows against the euro and Swiss franc as higher interest rates at home did nothing to deter speculative sellers.

entry.title: China's power reforms, global data centre buildout usher in battery boom
entry.summary: A revamp of China's electricity market is boosting the economics of storing power just as international demand surges, sparking a boom for the Chinese energy storage manufacturers that already dominate globally.

entry.title: How to plan a family ski trip, according to an expert
entry.summary:
Families can take to the snowy slopes in Serre Chevalier on skis, sleds or snowboards. From bagging one of Europe‚Äôs few bargains to what not to pack, get your first family skiing trip off to a flying start with our expert guide.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
For many parents the idea of whisking your family off to the mountains one winter and learning to ski is a potent daydream. But it‚Äôs also strewn with both potential pitfalls and actual physical falls ‚Äî and eye-watering costs. But there‚Äôs a good reason why millions love it and return to the slopes year after year. One good day, skiing together in the sunshine, can light up a whole winter. Here‚Äôs how to improve your chances of a successful first trip.
Don‚Äôt rush into it. The m‚Ä¶

entry.title: Italy's Saipem wins offshore contract in Qatar for about $4 billion
entry.summary: Italy's Saipem said on Sunday it had been awarded an offshore engineering, procurement, construction and installation (EPCI) contract by QatarEnergy LNG in partnership with China's Offshore Oil Engineering Co (COOEC) .

entry.title: Is this Japanese peninsula the perfect spot to forest bathe?
entry.summary:
Yoshino Forest in Japan is home to some of the country's oldest and tallest cedars, with some trees over 1,000 years old and reaching heights of more than 164ft. In the country‚Äôs Yoshino forests, cedar and cypress have been tended for generations, offering an unmatched setting to experience one of the world‚Äôs most restorative wellness therapies.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Akimoto Nakai stands in a clearing within the cedarwoods, the babble of a mountain brook filling the morning air and the slanting light glinting on an axe clenched in his fist. Etched into the steel are symbols representing the elemental forces that have shaped this forest over centuries: one each for the wind and the rain, the sun and the earth. And yet, the forest‚Äôs ‚Ä¶

entry.title: An to face Wang in women's title clash at World Tour Finals
entry.summary: Paris Olympics gold medallist An Se-young beat Japan's Akane Yamaguchi 21-15 21-12 in the last four of badminton's World Tour Final in Hangzhou on Saturday to set up a title clash with defending champion Wang Zhiyi.

entry.title: Explainer: What is so special about TikTok's algorithm?
entry.summary: The content recommendation algorithm that powers the online short video platform TikTok has once again come under the spotlight after the app's Chinese owner ByteDance signed binding agreements to form a joint venture that will hand control of operations of TikTok's U.S. app to American and global investors, including cloud computing company Oracle .

entry.title: China envoy visits Cambodia seeking to de-escalate fighting with Thailand
entry.summary: China‚Äôs special envoy for Asian affairs visited Phnom Penh this week to push for Cambodia and Thailand to de-escalate their fierce border fighting, Cambodia‚Äôs foreign ministry said on Saturday.

entry.title: Google warns staff with US visas against international travel due to embassy delays, Business Insider says
entry.summary: Alphabet's Google has advised some employees on U.S. visas to avoid international travel due to delays at embassies, Business Insider reported on Friday, citing an internal email.

entry.title: US drops Uganda deportation order against Chinese dissident, lawyer says
entry.summary: The U.S. on Friday dropped its effort to deport a Chinese national who helped document Beijing's alleged abuses against Uyghur Muslims to Uganda, the man's lawyer told Reuters.

entry.title: Humanoid robots take center stage at Silicon Valley summit

entry.title: Trump business network spreads
entry.summary: For the Wall Street Journal, David Uberti, Juanje G√≥mez, and Kara Dapena mapped‚Ä¶ Tags: business, family, Wall Street Journal

entry.title: French government to appeal court ruling on Shein
entry.summary: The French government will appeal a Paris court ruling that rejected its request for a three-month suspension of online platform Shein, it said in a statement on Friday after the court said such a suspension would be disproportionate.

entry.title: Golden Goose gets new majority owner as China's HSG buys stake from Permira
entry.summary: Italian luxury sneaker maker Golden Goose said on Friday that Chinese private equity firm HSG, formerly known as Sequoia Capital China, had become its majority shareholder after buying a stake from current owner Permira.

entry.title: How to plan a trip to Moab, Utah's red rock capital
entry.summary:
Moab is home to some of the US‚Äôs most dramatic landscapes, from gravity-defying sandstone arches and vibrant red-rock cliffs to winding canyons etched over millennia. Situated in eastern Utah along the Colorado River, this small desert city serves as the gateway to thousands of acres of rugged public lands, including Arches and Canyonlands national parks as well as Dead Horse Point and Utahraptor state parks. The region is famous for its outdoor adventures, such as whitewater rafting and mountain biking. However, it‚Äôs also a place to slow down, unplug and immerse yourself in nature. Whether you‚Äôre looking for family-friendly fun, high-octane experiences or peaceful moments amongst otherworldly scenery, here‚Äôs how to make the most of your time in Moab.
With kid-friendly activities an‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the Avatar team created the fantastic world of Fire and Ash
entry.summary:
In the film, the Medusoid (seen above) and other creatures are heavily influenced by nature and wildlife. The films co-production designer walks through how real-life organisms offer inspiration for the world of Pandora.
It‚Äôs no secret that celebrated filmmaker and National Geographic Explorer at Large James Cameron‚Äôs fantastical world of Pandora mirrors our planet Earth and imagines its inhabitants in a more harmonious relationship with their environment. And with Disney's Avatar: Fire and Ash hitting theaters on December 19, viewers will meet an exciting host of new clans and animals. (Disney is the parent company of National Geographic.)
One intriguing creature in the film doubles as a mode of transport used by a new clan called the Wind Traders. The blimp-like being‚Äîknown‚Ä¶

entry.title: This luxury resort in paradise doesn‚Äôt skimp on sustainability
entry.summary: The Brando, located on a remote island in French Polynesia, is a certified LEED Platinum property. Marlon Brando famously fell in love with this private island while filming Mutiny on the Bounty. Now it‚Äôs home to The Brando‚Äî"a rare resort that walks the walk when it comes to green initiatives,‚Äù according to our writer. ‚û§ Ultra-private accommodations:¬†The 35 big, tasteful standalone one-or-two-bedroom oceanfront villas (plus a couple of much larger, multi-bedroom villas) are all set quite well apart from another and positioned so that each has sight lines of the ocean rather than other rooms. Each has a plunge pool, outdoor shower, and direct beach access. ‚û§ Eco-oriented: A certified LEED Platinum property, The Brando uses solar power for more than 60 percent of it‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are the best wildlife photos of 2025
entry.summary:
Deep within Rio Doce State Park, in Brazil‚Äôs¬†remote¬†Atlantic Forest,¬†photographer Fernando Faciole¬†set up two camera¬†traps, and¬†then returned every¬†45 days¬†to change out the¬†batteries¬†and check the memory cards.¬†
His patience‚Äîand¬†willingness to deal with a lot of near-bites from¬†the¬†forest‚Äôs¬†ticks‚Äîpaid off.¬†Fewer than a dozen jaguars are thought to inhabit¬†the area¬†after decades of¬†deforestation.¬†Faciole¬†would have been lucky to have gotten any pictures of them, let alone one so stunningly posed.¬†
‚ÄúIt was the perfect position, with the jaguar looking at the camera, the tail, the framing,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt was super special for me.‚Äù¬†
Faciole‚Äôs¬†jaguar¬†portrait is just one of the¬†top¬†wildlife photos of 2025, selected by the photography staff at National Geographic. All together, th‚Ä¶

entry.title: First look at Australia's newest Great Walk‚Äîhere's what it's like
entry.summary:
Kangaroo Island is one of the two new multi-day walks to be added to Australia's collection of Great Walks in 2026. A new hiking route on Kangaroo Island takes walkers on a journey through Flinders Chase National Park via platypus-filled pools, windblown beaches and comfortable lighthouse stays.
This story is created by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Tasmanian Walking Company guide Olivia King stops in her tracks, her tan fedora and sand-coloured shirt blending into the bush. ‚ÄúWhat happens when the unthinkable happens?‚Äù she asks our group of a dozen walkers. ‚ÄúHow do you rebuild?‚Äù
The unthinkable did happen here on Kangaroo Island, which lies off the south coast of South Australia. The country‚Äôs third-largest isle has long been famed for its chiselled cliffs and win‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Book of Kells might not be Irish after all
entry.summary:
A page from the Book of Kells, ninth century illuminated manuscript. This page shows the Virgin and child, an unusual motif in northwestern Europe at that time. The text is a mysterious medieval marvel. A new book claims to know its true origin.
The Book of Kells‚Äîan illuminated manuscript of the Christian gospels, the New Testament books of Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, created c. A.D. 800‚Äîmay be the world‚Äôs most famous medieval manuscript.
On its pages,¬†a veritable menagerie is set loose: sinuous letters resolving into cats and human heads; solemn-faced apostles peering out from nests of impossibly complex Celtic knotwork; chickens and wolves tiptoeing through the text. Words and letters bloom into layer upon layer of ornament. Each of these images, often smaller than a qua‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to sample the ‚Äòmetaphysical wellness‚Äô trend
entry.summary:
Metaphysical wellness treatments are becoming increasingly popular throughout the United States. Whether you‚Äôre interested in astrology or looking to experiment with tarot, these getaways offer you an opportunity to experiment while you‚Äôre between massages.
Metaphysical practices, mysticism, and what was called the ‚ÄúNew Age Movement‚Äù for its revival of ancient practices isn‚Äôt anything new‚Äîreligious practices like Hinduism and Buddhism have always included mystical elements, and spiritual mediums have been pushing the boundaries since the mid-1800s.¬†
Metaphysics is the intangible, so much so that Stanford University‚Äôs Encyclopedia of Philosophy entry begins with ‚ÄúIt is not easy to say what metaphysics is.‚Äù
Though not based in science, metaphysical sessions are becoming an ‚Ä¶

entry.title: This unlikely Lithuanian city is Europe‚Äôs ‚ÄòChristmas Capital‚Äô
entry.summary:
Visitors take a selfie in front of an illuminated Christmas tree at Cathedral Square in Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, and the 2025 Christmas Capital of Europe. Vilnius boasts Michelin-starred restaurants, a UNESCO-designated Old Town, a historic prison turned artist hangout, and a hip, bohemian neighborhood worth visiting.
Grand Duke Gediminas founded Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, in¬†the 14th century. Today, the nearly century-old city is as contemporary as it is classic, a dichotomy that defines so much of life in Vilnius.¬†
After the fall of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s, Lithuania, like most of the former Soviet Bloc, spent a decade in turmoil. During the ‚ÄúWild Nineties,‚Äù the region was searching for a steady footing while grappling with its newfound independ‚Ä¶

entry.title: US lawmakers urge Pentagon to add DeepSeek, Xiaomi to list of firms allegedly aiding Chinese military
entry.summary: A group of nine U.S. lawmakers sent a letter to U.S. Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth this week urging the Pentagon to add a slew of Chinese technology firms to a list of entities allegedly assisting the Chinese military.

entry.title: Exclusive: Nexperia's China unit switches to local firms for wafer supplies, document shows
entry.summary: The Chinese unit of Netherlands-based Nexperia has locked in supplies of silicon wafers from local firms to cover its entire 2026 production for one type of power chip, a document showed, after the Dutch firm stopped supplying the raw material in a corporate dispute.

entry.title: French court orders Shein to verify age for adult products, rejects government suspension request
entry.summary: A Paris court ordered Shein to implement age verification measures for any adult products sold via its French website and set a 10,000 euro ($11,709) fine for any breach, after uproar over childlike sex dolls sold on its marketplace.

entry.title: Copper nears record high as supply tightness back in focus
entry.summary: Copper inched up on Friday to move within $25 of the record high after another bullish forecast by Goldman Sachs highlighted mine supply constraints.

entry.title: Security Council hears of fading election prospects in Libya
entry.summary: The path to long-awaited elections in Libya is paved with complications but they can be overcome, the UN Special Representative for the country said on Friday in a briefing to the Security Council.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: More UN staff detentions in Yemen, peacekeepers killed in Sudan sent home, attacks in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Friday condemned the arbitrary detention of 10 more UN personnel by Houthi de facto authorities in Yemen, warning that the growing crackdown is crippling humanitarian operations and putting millions of lives at risk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council renews DR Congo peacekeeping mission amid renewed M23 offensives in the east
entry.summary: The UN Security Council on Friday unanimously extended the mandate of the UN peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) for another year, as fighting in the country‚Äôs east intensified amid renewed offensives by the M23 rebel group.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN urges calm in Bangladesh after killing of protest leader sparks unrest
entry.summary: The United Nations has urged calm in Bangladesh after the killing of a prominent youth protest leader sparked fresh unrest, raising concerns about political violence and the safety of civic space as the country prepares for elections early next year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Calming the mind and promoting global peace on World Meditation Day
entry.summary: Meditation, which has its roots in religious, yogic and secular traditions from various civilisations, calls for living in the present moment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan: UN Mission condemns killing of a staff member in Wau, calls for a swift investigation
entry.summary: The United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) called on Friday for an investigation into the killing of one of its staff members in Wau, Western Bahr el Ghazal state.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza famine pushed back, but millions still face hunger and malnutrition, UN says
entry.summary: Food security in Gaza has improved since the ceasefire declared in October, pushing back famine conditions, but the situation remains critical with more than three-quarters of the population still facing acute hunger and malnutrition, a new UN-backed analysis has found.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Kordofan‚Äôs El-Obeid ‚Äòone or two steps‚Äô away from being attacked
entry.summary: As fighting escalates in Sudan, ‚Äúpeople are scared, people are fleeing their homes‚Äù, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Friday, noting that more than 50,000 people have been uprooted since late October in the Kordofans region alone.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Knife-wielding attacker kills three in Taipei, dies during police chase
entry.summary: Three people were killed and five injured when a knife-wielding attacker went on a rampage in central Taipei on Friday, before then dying during a police chase after falling from a building, the premier said.

entry.title: UK government acknowledges it is investigating cyber incident after media reports
entry.summary: The British government says it is investigating a ‚Äúcyber incident‚Äù following news reports that hackers linked to China have gained access to thousands of confidential documents held by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office.

entry.title: Wall St climbs on tech strength, Nike tumbles on China miss
entry.summary: Wall Street's main indexes gained on Friday, as technology stocks extended their rebound from a selloff earlier in the week, while Nike tumbled after weak China sales weighed on its quarterly results.

entry.title: Foxtron to acquire Yulon Motor‚Äôs Luxgen for $25 million
entry.summary: Foxtron Vehicle Technologies , a joint venture between Taiwan‚Äôs Foxconn and Yulon Motor , said on Friday it would acquire Yulon Motor‚Äôs Luxgen passenger-car brand for T$787.6 million ($24.95 million).

entry.title: Exclusive: Nexperia's China unit switches to local firms for wafer supplies- document
entry.summary: The Chinese unit of Netherlands-based Nexperia has locked in supplies of silicon wafers from local firms to cover its entire 2026 production of a key product, a document showed, after the Dutch firm stopped supplying the raw material in a corporate dispute.

entry.title: China files WTO case against Indian tariffs, subsidies
entry.summary: China has filed a case against India's tariffs on information and communications technology products and Indian photovoltaic subsidies with the World Trade Organisation, the Chinese commerce ministry said in a statement released on Friday.

entry.title: China threatens 'forceful measures' over US arms sales package to Taiwan
entry.summary: China's military will step up training and "take forceful measures" to safeguard the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity, the defence ministry said on Friday in response to a planned $11.1 billion U.S. arms sales package to Taiwan.

entry.title: China, US seek Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire ahead of ASEAN meeting
entry.summary: China and the U.S. are renewing their separate efforts to reach a ceasefire between Thailand and Cambodia, days ahead of a special meeting of Southeast Asian ministers on the border conflict, the worst fighting between the two in recent history.

entry.title: Italy ends probes on Stellantis, Volkswagen, Tesla, BYD over EV consumer info
entry.summary: Italy's competition authority said on Friday it had closed probes of BYD , Stellantis , Tesla and Volkswagen for allegedly misleading consumers on the performance of their electric vehicles.

entry.title: Debt boom signals yuan's arrival as a funding currency
entry.summary: Investors are snapping up yuan credits and surging yuan lending is poised to overtake overseas dollar loans at Chinese banks as attractive pricing helps drive a sustained push by Beijing to put the yuan on the global stage.

entry.title: China urges US not to implement China provisions in defence bill
entry.summary: China urged the U.S. on Friday to not implement "negative, China-related provisions" laid out in a U.S. defence bill, saying it is "strongly dissatisfied and firmly opposed" and has lodged repeated representations with Washington.

entry.title: Editor‚Äôs Pick: Best of Data Journalism from 2025
entry.summary: Our roundup of standout data journalism from the past year highlights projects that delve into conflicts in the Middle East, Ukraine, and Africa, that explore the rise of AI, and interrogate global trade wars.

entry.title: China set to keep rates steady for seventh month despite slowing economy
entry.summary: China is expected to leave benchmark lending rates unchanged for a seventh consecutive month in December, a Reuters survey showed, despite a depressed economy and deepening woes in the property sector.

entry.title: UK government was hacked in October, minister confirms
entry.summary: British trade department minister Chris Bryant said the government had been hacked in October, partly confirming a report in the Sun newspaper, which said a Chinese group had breached systems to access Foreign Office data.

entry.title: An beats Yamaguchi to top group at World Tour Finals
entry.summary: South Korea's An Se-young finished top of Group A at badminton's World Tour Finals in Hangzhou on Friday after defeating world champion Akane Yamaguchi 14-21 21-5 21-14, while Thailand's Ratchanok Intanon beat China's Han Yue to advance.

entry.title: From Alsatians to autonomy: China seeks home-grown edge in police dogs
entry.summary: China's national security authorities are urging police across the country to favour the use of a home-grown dog breed over German Shepherds, Rottweilers, Malinois and Springer Spaniels, as Beijing relentlessly pursues self-reliance.

entry.title: Keith Lee named 'creator of the year' at first-ever US TikTok awards
entry.summary: Content creators across dance, music, sports, fashion, entertainment and education gathered in Hollywood on Thursday for the first U.S. TikTok Awards, featuring Labubu dolls launched from a T-shirt cannon, a giant selfie challenge, skits, and viral moment reenactments.

entry.title: Explainer: Taiwan's political deadlock and the potential for new elections
entry.summary: Taiwan is in a political deadlock over the government refusing to enact amendments to a local government spending law passed by the opposition-controlled parliament, saying the plan is fiscally unsound and has been done without proper consultation.

entry.title: Morning Bid: Japan's savers get to party like it's 1999
entry.summary: A look at the day ahead in European and global markets from Wayne Cole.

entry.title: Nike‚Äôs China conundrum deepens as turnaround stagnates
entry.summary: Nike is running out of time to prove its China playbook works. The U.S. sportswear giant‚Äôs sixth straight quarterly sales decline in the country - including a 20% drop in footwear - underscores how a market once seen as a growth engine has become its biggest pressure point.

entry.title: As global scrutiny grows, Chinese firms look to call Singapore home
entry.summary: A growing number of Chinese companies are looking to domicile in Singapore, betting a move to the trade-focused city-state would reduce risks their operations get disrupted by Sino-U.S. geopolitical tensions.

entry.title: Exclusive: US launches review of advanced Nvidia AI chip sales to China, sources say
entry.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration has launched a review that could result in the first shipments to China of Nvidia's second-most powerful AI chips, five sources said, making good on his pledge to allow the controversial sales.

entry.title: An interstellar comet is passing by Earth tonight‚Äîhere‚Äôs how to see it
entry.summary:
Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS streaks across the sky with a blue plasma tail, photographed from June Lake, California, on December 14, 2025. Comet 3I/ATLAS is a rare visitor passing briefly through our solar system. Here‚Äôs how to find it in the night sky‚Äîand what you‚Äôll need to catch a glimpse.
One of only three known interstellar objects ever detected is making a one-time pass through our solar system. Known as comet 3I/ATLAS, it originated around another star and will reach its closest approach to Earth in the early hours of December 19. Here‚Äôs everything you need to know to catch a glimpse of the comet tonight.
3I/ATLAS is a comet, a ball of ice, dust, and frozen gases‚Äîor a ‚Äúcosmic snowball,‚Äù as NASA calls them. As they approach the sun, they heat up and develop the long ta‚Ä¶

entry.title: Asia stocks join Wall St rally, brace for BOJ hike
entry.summary: Asian share markets rebounded on Friday as a turnaround in tech lifted Wall Street, leaving investors counting down to a likely hike in interest rates from the Bank of Japan that could cause waves for currencies and bonds.

entry.title: Wanxiang to pay $53 million to resolve US probe into imported Chinese auto parts, DOJ says
entry.summary: The Justice Department said Thursday it had reached a settlement with the U.S. arm of Chinese auto parts supplier Wanxiang over import tariffs owed on wheel hub assemblies and other parts imported from China over a five-year period.

entry.title: TikTok signs deal to sell US unit to American investor-led venture
entry.summary: TikTok's Chinese owner, ByteDance, signed binding agreements with three major investors to sell just over 80% of the company's U.S. assets to American and global investors to avoid a U.S. government ban, TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew told employees on Thursday.

entry.title: How Trump's Venezuela embargo could put Taiwan at risk
entry.summary: Donald Trump's decision to impose a partial blockade on Venezuela marks a dramatic escalation in U.S. pressure on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, but it also risks undermining a top U.S. policy goal: deterring a potential Chinese naval encirclement of Taiwan.

entry.title: Venezuela authorizes two unsanctioned loaded oil supertankers to depart, sources say
entry.summary: Venezuela on Thursday authorized two very large crude carriers (VLCC) to set sail for China, according to two sources familiar with Venezuela's oil export operations. They would be only the second and third supertankers to depart the country since the U.S. seized a ship carrying Venezuelan oil last week.

entry.title: Pirelli says 99.3% of 500 mln euro bond converted, diluting Sinochem and Camfin stakes
entry.summary: Tyremaker Pirelli said on Thursday nearly all holders of its 500 million euro ($587 million) bond expiring this month have chosen to convert it into new shares in the company, diluting the stakes held by the group's existing investors.

entry.title: India imposes anti-dumping duty on some steel imports from China
entry.summary: India has imposed anti-dumping duty on cold rolled steel imports from China for five years to protect the domestic industry, it said late on Thursday.

entry.title: This region could be the UK's next great food break‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
Douglas fir, one of the foraged ingredients used at The Black Swan at Oldstead, is served with yoghurt. In and around the Howardian Hills, chefs are crafting dishes that sing of this county‚Äôs rich larder, with ingredients like zesty spruce tips and salted rhubarb adding pizazz to locally sourced fish, meat and game.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
I‚Äôm standing on a quiet country path in Hovingham, North Yorkshire, sniffing a pungent handful of wild mustard. Josh Overington, chef-proprietor of the village‚Äôs fine-dining restaurant M√Ωse, which also runs foraging courses, tugs me another treasure from the foliage ‚Äî a tuft of citrussy fireweed.
The young chef, born in the nearby market town of Pocklington, explains that elderflower can be use‚Ä¶

entry.title: Finland's far-right party reprimands two MPs over racism scandal

entry.title: Swiss gold exports drop in November as shipments to India plunge
entry.summary: Gold exports from Switzerland fell 15% month on month in November as shipments to India dropped to their lowest since February, Swiss customs data showed on Thursday.

entry.title: Acer, Asus and Hisense win UK court ruling in video streaming patent dispute with Nokia
entry.summary: Taiwanese tech companies Acer and Asus and China-based Hisense won a ruling from London's High Court on Thursday in their global patent dispute with Nokia over video coding technology.

entry.title: Times New Roman vs. Calibri typefaces
entry.summary: The State Department decided that they will use Times New Roman instead of‚Ä¶ Tags: Calibri, Times New Roman, typogrpahy

entry.title: Senators want US construction firms to detail use of DJI drones in government contracts
entry.summary: Two U.S senators on Thursday asked several U.S. construction companies to detail the use of Chinese-made DJI drones in government contracts and at sensitive national security facilities, saying the issue raised national security concerns.

entry.title: ‚úö Ridgeline chart for fun and clarity
entry.summary: This week, we round off 2025 with a chart breakdown for one of my favorite types, the ridgeline chart. It has layers. Tags: breakdown

entry.title: What your mouth can reveal about your health
entry.summary:
More than a millennium ago, the Persian physician Avicenna suggested that oral maladies could affect the entire body. Today, modern research is showing just how far those effects may reach‚Äîrevealing that the microbes living on our teeth, tongue, and gums could offer clues to the early detection and prevention of disease throughout the body.
A recent study in JAMA Oncology found that 27 species of oral bacteria and fungi were associated with a 3.5-fold higher risk of developing pancreatic cancer. Using whole-genome sequencing, researchers discovered that patients with evidence of certain microbes in their mouths were significantly more likely to be diagnosed with the disease.
‚ÄúBy profiling bacterial and fungal populations in the mouth, oncologists may be able to flag those most in‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who was Constantine?
entry.summary: Popular myth has it that in October A.D. 312, on the outskirts of Rome, a moment of inner transformation reshaped the course of Western history: Constantine, on the brink of battle for the imperial throne, converted to Christianity. Constantine reportedly had a strange but powerful vision: a cross of light blazing in the sky, accompanied by the Greek words ‚ÄúConquer by this‚Äù more commonly known in Latin as In hoc signo vinces, or ‚ÄúIn this sign you will conquer.‚Äù When he emerged victorious at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge against his rival Maxentius for the throne of the Roman Empire, he interpreted his vision as a divine intervention from God. Christians in the Roman Empire had been a persecuted minority restricted to meeting in secret. Within just a few decades of the emperor‚Äôs conversi‚Ä¶

entry.title: A calendar of New Year celebrations around the world
entry.summary:
New Year‚Äôs Day marks the first day of the Gregorian calendar. As many people gear up to celebrate the start of their New Year at the beginning of January, we take a look at how other cultures and countries mark the beginning of a new year.
Ring in the New Year live from Times Square with star-studded performances, global celebrations, and your favorite hosts! Watch Dick Clark‚Äôs New Year‚Äôs Rockin‚Äô Eve with Ryan Seacrest¬†LIVE December 31 on ABC. This article was adapted from National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The marking of a New Year is an age-old tradition around the world ‚Äî food, fireworks and reflection with friends and family are common threads, but ultimately this varies between different calendars, religions and cultures. While the Gregorian calendar (introduced throug‚Ä¶

entry.title: Too much alone time has a startling effect on the teenage brain
entry.summary:
A new study suggests that lower levels of social interaction during adolescence are linked to differences in brain development, including regions involved in social cognition and decision-making. As teens spend less time with their friends in person, scientists are beginning to uncover how isolation may affect the developing ‚Äúsocial brain." Here‚Äôs what we know‚Äîand when parents should be concerned.
For generations, adolescence has been defined as a time of social connection‚Äîhanging out with friends, dating, and developing bonds outside the family. These interactions aren‚Äôt just cultural rites of passage; they help shape how young brains learn to navigate emotions, relationships, and risk.
But that social landscape is changing. In recent years, teens have been spending less time‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: Access to food improves but living conditions remain dire
entry.summary: A pregnant woman in Gaza thought she might lose her child because of malnourishment. Ten days ago, she gave birth and is now in recovery thanks to World Food Programme (WFP) facilities that are back up and running again, the agency‚Äôs representative for Palestine said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: UN to evacuate Kadugli base in Sudan, celebrating migrant contributions, ending colonialism
entry.summary: The United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) will evacuate its logistics base in Kadugli, Sudan, in the wake of the ‚Äúheinous attack‚Äù this past weekend that killed six Bangladeshi peacekeepers and seriously injured eight others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Can traditional medicine strengthen modern healthcare? An expert‚ÄØweighs‚ÄØin
entry.summary: Ginger and cinnamon are more than just‚ÄØingredients. Along with other‚ÄØspices, their medicinal value‚ÄØis gaining‚ÄØboth‚ÄØattention‚ÄØand legitimacy.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria‚Äôs humanitarian needs remain high despite reduced violence, UN warns
entry.summary: Humanitarian needs in Syria remain immense despite a year of reduced violence and political change, with millions still displaced, basic services strained and funding shortfalls threatening aid operations, senior UN officials said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilians at risk amid escalating Thailand-Cambodia conflict: UN rights chief
entry.summary: Intensifying air strikes and heavy artillery fire across¬†Thailand and¬†Cambodia have left civilians increasingly at risk, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker T√ºrk warned on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: World urged not to ignore 'gruesome sexual violence'
entry.summary: Harrowing new details emerged on Thursday in a UN report detailing targeted sexual violence and summary executions in Sudan‚Äôs North Darfur region, attributed to paramilitary fighters who overran the city of El Fasher in late October.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Morning Bid: Optics and Oracles
entry.summary: Investors' top focus today is the delayed - and slightly unusual - U.S. consumer price inflation report, which will be an important marker for whether the Federal Reserve is likely to keep cutting interest rates next year.

entry.title: Taiwan rattled by 5.1 magnitude quake, no immediate reports of damage
entry.summary: A 5.1 magnitude earthquake struck 18 km (11 miles) off eastern Taiwan's Hualien city on Thursday, the island's weather administration said, with no immediate reports of damage.

entry.title: China says arms trade with Cambodia, Thailand unrelated to border conflict
entry.summary: China's defence cooperation with Cambodia and Thailand, including arms trade, "does not target any third party ... and is completely unrelated to the Cambodia-Thailand border conflict," its defence ministry said on Thursday.

entry.title: Island of the hornbills
entry.summary: Why the stunning rhinoceros hornbills are the farmers of the rainforest and a powerful avian symbol of regeneration - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Long live the aeonophiles!
entry.summary: The discovery of organisms that have been alive for many thousands of years requires a revolution in how we understand life - by Karen G Lloyd Read on Aeon

entry.title: EU risks losing out to China and US with climate aims, new Czech minister says
entry.summary: The European Union must rethink its climate aims or risk losing out to China and the United States, new Czech Industry Minister Karel Havlicek said as he called on allies to halt the bloc's next-generation emissions trading scheme.

entry.title: Spanish police search laboratory in African swine fever probe
entry.summary: Spanish police searched a state-funded laboratory near Barcelona on Thursday as part of an investigation into the origin of the African swine fever outbreak in the same area, regional police said.

entry.title: China's Momenta teams up with Grab on autonomous driving in Southeast Asia
entry.summary: China's autonomous driving startup Momenta has entered a strategic partnership with Singapore-based Grab , the companies said on Thursday.

entry.title: Tidal wave of Chinese tea brands place bets on winning over American tastebuds
entry.summary: Amanda Wang, co-founder of Chinese fast-growing beverage chain Ningji Lemon Tea, made four research trips to the U.S. before launching Bobobaba, designed to cater specifically to American tastes.

entry.title: Gold Mining Disasters, Lost Refugee Boats, AI-Powered Protest Crackdowns: Best Investigative Stories from Turkey in 2025
entry.summary: Investigative journalism in the country has shown remarkable resilience, depth, and impact despite operating under difficult conditions.

entry.title: China says it is granting new, streamlined rare earth export licences
entry.summary: China's Commerce Ministry said on Thursday that it had granted several general licenses for rare earth exports, a new category of permit that aims to speed up shipments of the vital elements.

entry.title: EU must reform or risk irrelevance, Blair and Dimon say
entry.summary: The European Union must reform or risk becoming irrelevant as the rivalry between China and the U.S. sparks a new era without precedent, posing challenges on security, energy, technology and trade, a report led by Tony Blair and Jamie Dimon says.

entry.title: China launches $113 billion free-trade experiment on Hainan island
entry.summary: China on Thursday split off a Belgium-sized island with an economy comparable to a mid-ranked country from the mainland for customs processing, part of a bid to join a major trans-Pacific trade deal and establish a new Hong Kong-style commercial hub.

entry.title: Morning Bid: BoE to make the cut as others stay the course
entry.summary: A look at the day ahead in European and global markets from Tom Westbrook.

entry.title: India streamlines visa rules in boost for Chinese professionals
entry.summary: India has reformed its business visa regime to ease movement of foreign engineers and technicians, the government said in a statement, which will be a boost local firms leaning on Chinese professionals for manufacturing services.

entry.title: China Vanke begins second meeting with holders of 2 billion yuan bond
entry.summary: Cash-strapped China Vanke kicked off a second meeting with holders of a 2 billion yuan ($283.99 million) bond on Thursday, as it scrambles to extend its debt payments with bondholders and banks in an effort to avoid a default.

entry.title: Despite tariffs, China consumer giants push into the US as domestic market stalls
entry.summary: Lured by the promise of richer margins, a wave of Chinese consumer brands is making deeper inroads into American retail to offset sluggish spending at home.

author.name: Casey Hall, Nicholas Brown, Helen Reid

entry.title: US announces massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion
entry.summary: The Trump administration has announced a massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion, including medium-range missiles, howitzers and drones, a move that is sure to infuriate China.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: Tech jitters dent stocks before central banks take centre stage
entry.summary: Asian shares fell on Thursday as the tech sector took a beating on renewed angst about AI spending, while investors braced for a wave of central bank meetings set to underscore policy divergence worldwide.

entry.title: Taiwan says US has initiated $11.1 billion arms sale procedure
entry.summary: Taiwan's defence ministry said on Thursday the U.S. government has initiated the congressional notification procedure for $11.1 billion in arms sales to Taiwan, in a show of support for Taipei which is under increasing military pressure from China.

entry.title: How to see the Southwest‚Äôs best red rock formations‚Äîwithout the crowds
entry.summary:
Located near Grand Junction, Colorado, the Colorado National Monument, or ‚Äúmini-Grand Canyon,‚Äù has six distinct canyons and 43 trails. Its red rocks, towering formations, and sheer cliffs are visible along the scenic Rim Rock Drive. Beneath the cliffs of western Colorado, a billion years of geologic history unfolds‚Äîand a century-old dream of accessibility still shapes the land.
The Colorado National Monument is blissfully quiet‚Äîa rare occurrence in national parks in the Southwest‚Äîeven though it is located a few miles west of¬†Grand Junction,¬†the largest city in western Colorado.
The¬†Grand Canyon¬†attracted more than four million visitors in 2024, but the Colorado National Monument, also known as the mini-Grand Canyon, welcomes 488,000 people¬†a year.¬†¬†

entry.title: Focus: No small token: Chinese firms convert prized trees, tea into digital assets
entry.summary: On the Chinese tropical island of Hainan, Huanghuali trees - a rare kind of rosewood - are being photographed so that they can be turned into digital assets.

entry.title: China sues after Missouri seeks to collect on $25 billion court judgement, prosecutor says
entry.summary: Missouri‚Äôs top prosecutor says China is suing after the state pressed federal officials for help collecting on a roughly $25 billion court judgment related to the COVID-19 pandemic.

entry.title: Trading Day: Tech slumps, oil spikes
entry.summary: U.S. shares sank on Wednesday, with tech hit by renewed worries over the AI trade, while Washington's blockade of all sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela lifted oil prices from their five-year lows.

entry.title: Republican lawmakers decry Intel's testing of Chinese-linked tools after Reuters report
entry.summary: Republican lawmakers accused Intel this week of threatening U.S. national security after Reuters revealed the chipmaker was evaluating chipmaking equipment made by a company with deep ties to China and overseas units sanctioned by the U.S. government.

entry.title: Can vitamin D lower risk of heart attack?
entry.summary: Vitamin D is thought to play a protective role in heart health, perhaps linked to its anti-inflammatory properties. Now scientists are starting to tease out whether vitamin D supplements might make a difference. Low levels of vitamin D seem to raise your risk of heart attack but scientists are still figuring out why‚Äîand whether supplements might help protect you. Vitamin D has long been known to play an important role in the body‚Äîand not getting enough of it has been¬†linked to a number of health issues, including an increased risk of certain types of cancers and autoimmune diseases. But there‚Äôs one link that scientists are still researching. ‚ÄúThere¬†is a long association with vitamin ‚Ä¶

entry.title: A year after L.A.'s wildfires, survivors share their stories
entry.summary: When Marla Peppers (here with Ryan Shoop and Rick Shoop) saw flames on the ridge above her Altadena home, she recognized the threat before the rest of her family. ‚ÄúPack, pack, pack!‚Äù she shouted. They saved their dog. They lost their cat, their home of almost 22 years, and nearly all their belongings. Today they‚Äôre among more than a dozen fire-displaced families living in an apartment complex and are awaiting construction on their new house, on the same lot as the destroyed one. Nearly 60 square miles burned and 100,000 people were displaced. Now many are holding on to what they found‚Äîin their homes and in themselves‚Äîafter the flames had passed. In the era of megadisasters,¬†language fails us. We reach for an adjective‚Äîthe¬†worst¬†storm, the¬†deadliest¬†flood‚Ä¶

entry.title: The global hunt to unlock the healing powers of ‚Ä¶ poop
entry.summary:
Inside a petri dish, bacterial colonies (appearing as dark spots) grow from stool collected from a person living in an isolated community near San Marcos Sierras, Argentina. This is one of many such dishes at the Global Microbiome Conservancy (GMbC), founded to collect and preserve microbial diversity worldwide. Scientists have discovered that gut-born bacteria may hold the secret for treatments of everything from IBD to Parkinson‚Äôs disease. Now they just need samples from the people living in the most isolated, nonindustrialized places on Earth. It‚Äôs a messy process, for many reasons.
The first Bajau volunteers pulled up in canoes around 11 a.m. and gathered on a rickety wooden balcony surrounded by the turquoise expanse of the Sulu Sea. They were the intrepid ones. Over‚Ä¶

entry.title: Were there three Nativity wise men‚Äîor twelve?
entry.summary:
"The Magi Journeying" by James Tissot. Tradition has landed on three wise men for the Nativity story but early and medieval Christian sources listed anywhere from two to twelve kings from the east. Early Christian sources differ on how many Magi visited the infant Jesus, and whether they were kings at all.
Few scenes in the Christian imagination are as iconic as the three travelers kneeling before the infant Jesus, their camels waiting patiently as they present gold, frankincense, and myrrh. Yet these visitors‚Äîvariously called wise men, astrologers, or kings‚Äîremain among the most mysterious figures in the biblical world.
The Gospel of Matthew, the only canonical source to mention them, provides minimal details about who they were or what compelled them to undertake a long jour‚Ä¶

entry.title: G7 condemns prosecution of Jimmy Lai, calls for his release
entry.summary: Foreign ministers from the Group of Seven on Wednesday condemned the prosecution of Hong Kong pro-democracy campaigner Jimmy Lai, who was found guilty of collusion with foreign forces this week.

entry.title: China voices support for Venezuela, says it opposes 'unilateral bullying'
entry.summary: China opposes "unilateral bullying" and supports countries in safeguarding their own sovereignty, Foreign Minister Wang Yi told his Venezuelan counterpart on Wednesday, as U.S. President Donald Trump ramps up pressure on the South American country.

entry.title: Finland's prime minister apologises to Asian nations over racism scandal

entry.title: Exclusive: How China built its ‚ÄòManhattan Project‚Äô to rival the West in AI chips
entry.summary: In a high-security Shenzhen laboratory, Chinese scientists have built what Washington has spent years trying to prevent: a prototype of a machine capable of producing the cutting-edge semiconductor chips that power artificial intelligence, smartphones and weapons central to Western military dominance, Reuters has learned.

entry.title: Gold forecast to glitter again next year despite biggest gain since 1979
entry.summary: Gold has made its biggest jump since the 1979 oil crisis in 2025 -- with prices doubling in the last two years -- a performance which might previously have meant forecasts of a big correction.

entry.title: Crimean Tatar artist moulds new path through clay in wartime Ukraine
entry.summary: Through her ceramics, Crimean Tatar artist Elvira Demerdzhi finds moments of calm and a sense of home amid the ongoing war in Ukraine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At UN, nations pledge people-first digital future, tighter AI safeguards
entry.summary: UN Member States on Wednesday pledged to narrow widening digital divides and put stronger safeguards around artificial intelligence (AI), as the General Assembly concluded a major review of how the world manages the Internet and fast-evolving digital technologies.

entry.title: Fifty days on, Jamaica struggles to rebuild after Hurricane Melissa‚Äôs unprecedented destruction
entry.summary: Fifty days have passed since Hurricane Melissa ravaged Jamaica, leaving behind an unprecedented trail of destruction.

entry.title: Aid agencies warn Gaza response at breaking point as Israel urged to lift new restrictions
entry.summary: Humanitarian agencies working in the Occupied Palestinian Territory (OPT) have warned that life-saving aid operations risk collapse unless Israel immediately lifts new barriers that are blocking access and forcing international charities to shut down.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Needs rise as people continue to flee fighting in Kordofan
entry.summary: Families continue to flee intense hostilities across the Kordofan region of Sudan and humanitarian needs are surging, the UN said in an update on Wednesday.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Progress on hunger in Asia-Pacific, key Gaza pipeline repaired, flu hits Europe hard
entry.summary: While the Asia and Pacific region has made notable progress in reducing hunger, persistent challenges remain in addressing malnutrition, food insecurity and unequal access to healthy diets, a new¬†UN report published on Wednesday concludes.

entry.title: Ukraine suffering continues as electricity is cut for days amid ongoing Russian attacks
entry.summary: Imagine living through a war and not being able to make a meal or heat your home; that‚Äôs the reality today for thousands of Ukrainians who‚Äôve seen repeated Russian attacks knock out their electricity for days at a time.

entry.title: Yemen on the brink: Guterres urges restraint, calls for release of UN detainees
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres called on Yemen‚Äôs leaders to return to the path of peace and release all UN personnel detained there, following a briefing to the Security Council on Wednesday.

entry.title: China exploits US-funded research on nuclear technology, a congressional report says

entry.title: China says Philippines distorted facts about incident near disputed atoll
entry.summary: China's defence ministry accused the Philippines on Wednesday of distorting the facts about an incident involving the Chinese coastguard and Filipino fishermen near a South China Sea shoal, a charge Manila strongly rejected.

entry.title: South Korean contractors on Taiwan submarines jailed for leaking documents
entry.summary: A South Korean court found two contractors that worked on Taiwan's submarine programme guilty of leaking designs for torpedo-launching systems, calling the case a potential "diplomatic burden" for Seoul, according to a ruling reviewed by Reuters.

entry.title: Bomba and bioluminescence‚ÄîPuerto Rico is full of surprises
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The inhabitants of San Juan aren‚Äôt early risers. At 9am, the city‚Äôs streets are largely empty. In the Plaza Col√≥n, there‚Äôs a cockerel scrabbling about in the flower beds. A kiosk selling coffee and empanadas is untroubled by customers.
‚ÄúWe like a slow start,‚Äù Laura Ortiz-Villamil confirms as we sit in the shade, the sun already blazing. In front of us is a statue of Christopher Columbus, a crucifix raised in his left hand. Among the first Europeans to barrel over the Atlantic, all eager to get their hands on whatever land they could, he ‚Äòdiscovered‚Äô Puerto Rico in 1493 and immediately claimed it for Spain.
‚ÄúThe Spanish called it Puerto Rico ‚Äî rich port ‚Äî wrongly believing there was gold here,‚Äù Laura says as we‚Ä¶

entry.title: Domestic demand to drive German recovery in 2026, says IMK
entry.summary: Germany's economy will next year experience its first domestically-driven recovery since reunification, breaking with decades of export-led growth, a forecast by the Macroeconomic Policy Institute IMK showed on Wednesday.

entry.title: GIJN Resource Center‚Äôs Top Guides and Tipsheets for 2025
entry.summary: Highlights this year have included guides to investigating landfill emissions, detecting AI content online, digging into caste discrimination, and material to help reporters investigate possible war crimes.

entry.title: Volkswagen battery business PowerCo looking more intensively at external funding
entry.summary: Volkswagen's PowerCo is looking more closely at external financing options as its stricken German parent reins in investment, the CEO of the battery business said.

entry.title: Japan visitor arrivals growth strong in November despite China travel warning
entry.summary: The ongoing diplomatic rift between Japan and China has had a muted impact on overall tourist numbers as visitors to Japan grew 10.4% year-on-year in November, the country's tourism board said on Wednesday.

entry.title: Global coal demand hit record high this year but is set to decline by 2030, IEA says.
entry.summary: Global coal demand reached a record high in 2025 but is expected to decline by 2030 as renewables, nuclear power and abundant natural gas squeeze its dominance in power generation, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday.

entry.title: TikTok monitored Grindr activity through third-party tracker, privacy group alleges
entry.summary: A privacy advocacy group, noyb, filed complaints to Austria's data protection authority on Wednesday against TikTok, Grindr and AppsFlyer, alleging these companies breached regional privacy laws, risking exposure of sensitive data.

entry.title: China's newest aircraft carrier sailed through Taiwan Strait, Taipei says
entry.summary: China's newest and most advanced aircraft carrier, the Fujian, sailed through the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday, Taiwan's defence ministry said, its first transit of the sensitive waterway since formally entering service last month.

entry.title: Shares meander after US jobs data, oil jumps on Venezuela blockade
entry.summary: Global share markets drifted on Wednesday after a mixed U.S. jobs reading failed to move the needle on the rate outlook there, leaving investors awaiting fresh cues for their next moves.

entry.title: In Patagonia, penguins are changing how pumas live
entry.summary:
Long absent from Argentinian Patagonia due to over-hunting, pumas have returned and started hunting local Magellanic penguins, which aren't normally part of the big cats' diet. A new study shows how this trend is shaping puma behavior. A natural experiment in a national park in Patagonia shows how the return of a large predator can reshape an ecosystem.
For decades, pumas preyed on sheep from ranches along Argentina‚Äôs coast, and ranchers hunted them‚Äîheavily.Pumas disappeared from the landscape. Then, in 2004, conservationists established Monte Le√≥n National Park in the region. As expected, once the hunting stopped, the big cats came back. And when they returned, they found a new player in their old neighborhood: Magellanic penguins.
What scientists did not anticipate was that ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Apple in talks with Indian chipmakers to assemble, package iPhone components, ET reports
entry.summary: Apple is in early discussions with Indian chipmakers to assemble and package components for the iPhone, the Economic Times reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Pakistan's military chief Asim Munir in spotlight over Trump's Gaza plan
entry.summary: Pakistan's most powerful military chief in decades faces the toughest test of his newly amassed powers as Washington pushes Islamabad to contribute troops to the Gaza stabilisation force, a move analysts say could spark domestic backlash.

entry.title: In the ocean's 'twilight zone,' new species await discovery
entry.summary:
Agat Bay, GuamThe sun shimmers across the glassy surface of Blue Hole, a heart-shaped underwater sinkhole, as two divers prepare to descend into its treacherous, turquoise abyss.
Sounds of buckles clicking, straps tightening, and gases swishing through tubes and tanks fill the tiny boat they‚Äôre aboard. The divers‚ÄîLuiz Rocha, a National Geographic Explorer and an ichthyologist and marine biologist from the California Academy of Sciences, and Mauritius Bell, the academy‚Äôs dive safety officer‚Äîare gearing up to head 330 feet below the surface, far beyond the reach of most scuba divers.
In this part of the ocean, known as the mesophotic or upper ‚Äútwilight zone,‚Äù sunlight is scarce and mysteries abound. Coral reefs thrive in the darkness, harboring life that often appears otherworldly.‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 breathtaking winter train journeys
entry.summary:
Europe‚Äôs Christmas markets hardly need help feeling charming, but somehow trains make them even more so. While the rails carry you past storybook villages and evergreen-studded hills, the journey itself becomes as much a part of the experience as the markets.
Here are 10 of the most breathtaking routes to savor the holidays by railway. Most routes here are covered by the Eurail Pass, but plan in advance for the busy Christmas season.
Route: Zermatt to St. Moritz
The Glacier Express earns its nickname as the world‚Äôs slowest express train, taking eight hours to traverse just 180 miles. But that‚Äôs a feature, not a bug. The panoramic windows frame the Swiss Alps like an IMAX screen, showing off¬†291 bridges, 91 tunnels, and the stately Landwasser Viaduct.
Time your journey‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rotisserie chicken and 10 more of the biggest food trends for 2026
entry.summary:
The coming year promises a wave of culinary ideas shaped by creativity, adaptation and nostalgia. From an ancient condiment to a matcha alternative, here are the food and drink trends to look out for.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Global tastes are ever-shifting, with culinary trends influenced by everything from wellness to supply-chain challenges. Around the world, chefs are seeking out foods that promise both flavour and functional benefits, rediscovering traditional techniques and utilising ingredients that might otherwise be discarded. At the same time, shortages of familiar favourites are nudging drinkers, diners and home cooks towards alternative varieties, while social media propels lesser-known cuisines into the spotlight. Here‚Äôs a‚Ä¶

entry.title: China ups demand to controlling stake in Panama ports deal, WSJ reports
entry.summary: China has upped its demands and is now pushing for state-owned ship operator Cosco to get a controlling stake in a $22.8 billion ports deal involving two contentious ports near the Panama Canal, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday citing people familiar with the matter.

entry.title: Why kimchi is king in Vancouver's Korean-Canadian community
entry.summary: Kimjang ‚Äî also known as winter kimchi party ‚Äî is a family affair that traditionally takes place in the year's final months. The traditional preparation and consumption of fermented cabbage has become the connective thread uniting the growing number of Korean-Canadians in British Columbia‚Äôs most multi-cultural city. Here, South Korea‚Äôs most prized culinary possession is a bridging cornerstone, from humble taverns to hip restaurants. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). I‚Äôm kneeling on the tiled floor of my host Annise Lee‚Äôs kitchen, sitting next to three of her pink-rubber-gloved Korean girlfriends. Wafts of pungent fish sauce fill the air. It‚Äôs a brisk November afternoon in the hills of Coquitlam, Vancouver‚Äôs unofficial Korea Town, and we‚Äôr‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the wrong pillow can wreck your sleep, says science
entry.summary:
Mounting research shows that pillow height and firmness are the strongest predictors of a good night‚Äôs sleep. Your pillow is one of the most powerful tools to help you fall asleep, stay asleep‚Äîand even ease your pain and improve posture during waking hours.
If you‚Äôve ever blamed a lousy night‚Äôs rest on stress, room temperature, or your mattress, you might be overlooking the smallest‚Äîand arguably most influential‚Äîpiece of your sleep setup: your pillow.
It may look like a basic rectangle of fluff, but sleep scientists say your pillow is one of the most powerful levers you have for regulating how quickly you fall asleep, how deeply you stay asleep, and how your neck, spine, breathing, and brain function long after you wake.¬†
‚ÄúSleep is a vulnerable state, and the brain and bo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Decoding the lost scripts of the ancient world
entry.summary:
The room we are in is¬†locked. It is windowless and lit from above by a fluorescent bulb. In the hallway outside‚Äîtwo stories beneath the city of London‚Äîattendants in dark suits patrol silently, giving the scene an air of cinematic drama. We‚Äôre in the downtown safety deposit center where the Iranian British art collector Kambiz Mahboubian, keeper of one of the world‚Äôs great troves of Near Eastern ancient art, houses some of his more precious pieces under lock and key.
Sitting across from me at a small table, Mahboubian reaches gingerly into a green plastic shopping bag from Waitrose & Partners, the British supermarket chain. From it, he produces a silver beaker covered with friezes long ago hammered out in high relief. As he places the teakettle-size vessel on the table, I can see on it‚Ä¶

entry.title: Chinese court sentences 27 people for smuggling antimony ingots
entry.summary: A Chinese court imposed jail sentences and fines on Tuesday on 27 people for shipping antimony ingots out of the country without export licences, in a ruling that highlights how China is tightening enforcement of its controls on strategic minerals.

entry.title: A life of joy and work
entry.summary: I am banned from working now, but as I look back on my long, challenging career in Afghanistan I feel hope for the future - by Najla & Asad Nariman Read on Aeon

entry.title: Thousands flock to a Tokyo zoo to see the last 2 pandas in Japan before their return to China
entry.summary: Thousands of people flocked to Tokyo‚Äôs Ueno zoo to have a last glimpse of the popular twin pandas that are set to return to their homeland in China next month.

entry.title: China puts anti-dumping tariff of up to 18.9% on imports of pork from the EU
entry.summary: China says it will begin imposing anti-dumping duties of up to 19.8% on imports of pork products from the European Union, after a review that could have resulted in tariffs of up to 62.4%.

author.name: China | Latest News from China Today | AP News

entry.title: India's exports defy tariffs, strengthen hand in US trade talks
entry.summary: India's exports leapt in November in defiance of U.S. President Donald Trump's steep tariffs, providing fresh leverage in ongoing trade talks with Washington and easing pressure on New Delhi to strike a quick deal.

entry.title: China lowers EU pork tariffs in final ruling after 18-month probe
entry.summary: China on Tuesday dramatically reduced tariffs on European Union pork imports worth over $2 billion in the final ruling of an anti-dumping investigation widely seen as a response to the bloc's duties on Chinese electric vehicles.

entry.title: China reiterates demand that Japanese PM retract Taiwan remarks
entry.summary: China on Tuesday reiterated its demand that Japan retract Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's remarks about Taiwan, more than a month after Takaichi said an attack on the democratically governed island could be deemed an existential threat to Japan.

entry.title: Japan's last two giant pandas are headed to China and fans just can't bear it
entry.summary: A day after news broke that Japan would soon lose its last two giant pandas to China, thousands of fans flocked to Tokyo's Ueno Zoo on Tuesday to catch a final glimpse, with many bidding the twins a tearful farewell.

entry.title: EU weighs scheme to allow combustion-engine vehicles after 2035, Handelsblatt reports
entry.summary: The European Commission is weighing a new compensation scheme that could allow car makers to sell combustion-engine vehicles beyond 2035, Germany's Handelsblatt newspaper reported on Tuesday, citing senior Commission sources.

entry.title: Americans like artificial Christmas trees even though few are made in US and prices are up
entry.summary: A trade association says new U.S. tariffs increased artificial Christmas tree prices by 10% to 15% this year as tree companies reduced their orders and raised prices to cover the higher import taxes.

entry.title: China AI chip firm Biren to launch Hong Kong IPO in coming weeks, sources say
entry.summary: Chinese AI chip startup Biren Technology aims to launch a Hong Kong initial public offering in the coming weeks, four sources with knowledge of the matter said.

entry.title: China seizes smuggled drugs on US tip
entry.summary: China seized 430 kg of smuggled cocaine last month, acting on information from the United States, the Chinese Public Security Ministry said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Stocks struggle before jobs data, central bank meetings
entry.summary: Asian equities tumbled while the dollar drifted near two-month lows on Tuesday, as investors adopted a cautious approach ahead of a slate of U.S. data, including the jobs report, that may help gauge the trajectory for Federal Reserve policy next year.

entry.title: Philippines denounces China's 'dangerous' and 'inhumane' actions against Filipino fishermen
entry.summary: Philippine Defense Secretary Gilberto Teodoro on Tuesday denounced what he described as "dangerous" and "inhumane" actions by Chinese maritime forces against Filipino fishermen in a contested South China Sea shoal last week.

entry.title: Taiwan says its military can respond rapidly to any sudden Chinese attack
entry.summary: Taiwan's military can respond rapidly to any sudden Chinese attack with all units able to operate under a decentralised mode of command without awaiting orders from above, Taipei's defence ministry said in a report to lawmakers.

entry.title: A harrowing tale of the first Americans to summit Everest
entry.summary:
Makalu, flanked by its subsidiary, Makalu II, dominates the scene. At left, Tibet‚Äôs 25,640-foot Chomo Lonzo looks across to the Kanchenjunga Massif, which armors the border between Nepal and Sikkim. On the distant right, India‚Äôs hot, dry plains appear dimly beyond the clouds. In May of 1963, National Geographic photographer and correspondent Barry C. Bishop was part of the first American team to summit Mount Everest. It was a feat that nearly drove the team mad, and one Bishop recounts in a cover story reprinted here.
This story originally published in the October 1963 issue of National Geographic magazine. See more digitized stories from our archives here.
‚ÄúLute, I think I‚Äôm going mad.‚Äù¬†I speak through clenched teeth to Lute Jerstad, lying beside me in the two-man tent. For‚Ä¶

entry.title: Oil moves lower on Ukraine talks, weak China data
entry.summary: Oil prices fell in early trading on Tuesday, adding to the previous session's losses, as prospects for a Russia-Ukraine peace deal appeared to strengthen, raising expectations of a potential easing of sanctions.

entry.title: EU to relent on combustion engines ban after auto industry pressure
entry.summary: The European Commission is set to backtrack on the EU's ban on new combustion-engine cars from 2035 by allowing up to 10% of non-electric vehicles after intense pressure from Germany, Italy and Europe's auto sector.

entry.title: Trading Day: Payrolls, Fed jitters mount
